title: Deno
description: The latest news from Deno Land Inc.

items.description: Deno 1.45 introduces workspaces and monorepo support, improved Node.js compatibility, updates to `deno install`, the new `deno init --lib` command, deprecation of `deno vendor`, Standard Library stabilization, upgrades to V8 12.7 and TypeScript 5.5.2, and more.
items.title: Deno 1.45: Workspace and Monorepo Support
items.author: Bartek Iwańczuk, Nayeem Rahman, Nathan Whitaker, Yoshiya Hinosawa, Asher Gomez

items.description: This new feature allows Subhosting users to configure their KV databases to back up data to their own S3-compatible object storage via APIs.
items.title: Introducing KV Backup for Deno Subhosting
items.author: Yusuke Tanaka, Andy Jiang

items.description: Quick, digestible bites of TypeScript goodness for Deno developers.  In this first bite, we introduce TypeScript, how to add type annotations  to your code and why you should.
items.title: A Gentle Intro to TypeScript
items.author: Jo Franchetti

items.description: Hono, a lightweight, fast, cross-platform web framework, is now on JSR.
items.title: Announcing Hono on JSR
items.author: Andy Jiang

items.description: When a customer reported performance issues with the Deno language server, we began a performance investigation that resulted in reducing auto-completion times from 6-8 seconds to under one second in large codebases. This is how we did it.
items.title: How We Made the Deno Language Server Ten Times Faster
items.author: Andy Jiang, Nathan Whitaker

items.description: The Guardian receives over 350 million unique page views. Learn how Deno helps the Guardian maximize web performance and adhere to accessibility standards to retain and grow their readership.
items.title: How the Guardian uses Deno to audit accessibility and performance across their 2.7 million articles
items.author: Andy Jiang

items.description: This new update simplifies programmatically managing custom domains, wildcard domains, subdomains for different deployments, and more.
items.title: Introducing More Flexible Domain Association for Deno Subhosting
items.author: Yusuke Tanaka, Andy Jiang

items.description: The Deno Standard Library is going to reach 1.0.0 shortly. We hope you try RC versions of the packages and give us feedback!
items.title: The stabilization process of the Standard Library has begun
items.author: Yoshiya Hinosawa

items.description: Deno 1.44 adds support for private npm registries, gRPC connections, improved Node.js compat with initial Next.js support, and significant performance improvements.
items.title: Deno 1.44: Private npm registries, improved Node.js compat, and performance boosts
items.author: Bartek Iwańczuk, Marvin Hagemeister, Ryan Dahl

items.description: When building a modern cloud platform to securely run untrusted code, it can be difficult to balance cost and performance. Here’s how we built Deno Deploy and Deno Subhosting.
items.title: How we built a secure, performant, multi-tenant cloud platform to run untrusted code
items.author: Bert Belder

items.description: The Deno Standard Library has moved to JSR, supporting SemVer ranges in imports and compatibility with Node.js, Cloudflare Workers, and more.
items.title: The Deno Standard Library is now available on JSR
items.author: Yoshiya Hinosawa, Jo Franchetti, Luca Casonato, Ryan Dahl, Asher Gomez

items.description: Writing good JSDocs for your JavaScript package is critical to its success. Here are some best practices for creating docs that helps your users be successful.
items.title: How to document your JavaScript package
items.author: Andy Jiang, Luca Casonato, Jo Franchetti, Leo Kettmeir

items.description: A low-code solution is a simple way to offer some flexibility for your users. However, to accommodate further customization (especially for enterprise users), you should have an “escape hatch” — simple, code-level customization. Here are three product scenarios and where an escape hatch makes most sense.
items.title: Your Low Code Solution Needs an Escape Hatch
items.author: Andy Jiang

items.description: Deno 1.43 enhances productivity with a faster language server, improved npm compatibility, a new `deno serve` subcommand, URL.parse() API, and announcements regarding Deno 2.
items.title: Deno 1.43: Improved Language Server performance
items.author: Andy Jiang, Bartek Iwańczuk, Marvin Hagemeister, Asher Gomez

items.description: Learn how building with Deno helped Slack launch their new development platform in weeks and not months.
items.title: How Slack used Deno to save months of engineering effort in launching their new platform
items.author: Andy Jiang

items.description: JSR introduces a new way to share JavaScript and TypeScript code across platforms, focusing on simplifying distribution without replacing existing package managers.
items.title: JSR Is Not Another Package Manager
items.author: Ryan Dahl

items.description: Hookdeck, an event gateway for distributed and async architecture, now has an SDK on JSR.
items.title: Announcing the Hookdeck SDK on JSR
items.author: Andy Jiang

items.description: Neon, a performant, edge-compatible, serverless Postgres driver, arrives on JSR.
items.title: Announcing the Neon Serverless Driver on JSR
items.author: Andy Jiang

items.description: TypeScript, one of the fastest growing languages, helps JavaScript developers improve code quality and productivity. But getting started can be challenging. Here's an introduction to TSConfig.
items.title: An intro to TSConfig for JavaScript Developers
items.author: Jo Franchetti

items.description: A modern JavaScript registry needs to be fast, reliable, and be as simple as possible for end users. Here's how we built JSR.
items.title: How we built JSR
items.author: Luca Casonato

items.description: Learn why Netlify chose Deno Subhosting over building their own solution with AWS Lambda to offer a successful edge functions product within weeks.
items.title: How Netlify used Deno Subhosting to build a successful edge functions product
items.author: Andy Jiang

items.description: Introducing a more simplified project creation flow in Deno Deploy, including seamless CI/CD setup, a more transparent build and deployment step, and more.
items.title: Introducing Simpler Project Creation in Deno Deploy
items.author: Andy Jiang, John Donmoyer

items.description: Deno 1.42 revolutionizes dependency management with the seamless integration of JSR, enhancing Node/npm compatibility and introducing significant performance improvements.
items.title: Deno 1.42: Better dependency management with JSR
items.author: Andy Jiang, Bartek Iwańczuk, David Sherret, Divy Srivastava, Nayeem Rahman

items.description: Deno Deploy’s command line interface, deployctl, is the simplest way to deploy your projects to the cloud. Here’s how to do it.
items.title: Introducing deployctl, the command line interface for Deno Deploy
items.author: Andy Jiang, Arnau Orriols

items.description: The JavaScript Registry (JSR) is a TypeScript-first, ESM-only module registry designed for the entire JavaScript ecosystem. Use JSR modules from Deno and npm-based projects. JSR is free and open source. Available today in public beta.
items.title: Introducing JSR - the JavaScript Registry
items.author: Ryan Dahl, Luca Casonato, Kevin Whinnery

items.description: Enabling your users to deploy and run code can make your platform more useful. Here's a guide to building a platform that deploys and runs untrusted user code via a browser IDE with Monaco, Next.js, and Subhosting.
items.title: How to add Monaco to a Next.js app and securely run untrusted user code
items.author: Andy Jiang

items.description: You answered our survey and we listened. Here’s what we’re working on currently and what you can expect from Deno next.
items.title: Survey Results and Roadmap
items.author: Andy Jiang, Alon Bonder

items.description: We've roughly halved the size of `deno compile` binaries, added official Linux ARM64 builds, continued to land Node.js compatibility improvements, and more.
items.title: Deno 1.41: smaller deno compile binaries
items.author: Andy Jiang, Bartek Iwańczuk

items.description: Webhooks, originally proposed as a way to consume asynchronous feeds, became the one-size-fits-all solution for integrating cloud software. Here’s why we think there’s a better solution.
items.title: Webhooks suck, but here are alternatives
items.author: Andy Jiang, Bert Belder

items.description: We revamped Deno Deploy’s onboarding to show you how easy it is to use Deno’s cloud primitives in your projects.
items.title: Introducing Deno Deploy onboarding tutorials
items.author: Andy Jiang, John Donmoyer

items.description: 2023 marked a significant step towards our vision of radically simplifying web development. Here are the biggest updates and what’s coming up next.
items.title: Deno in 2023
items.author: Andy Jiang, Ryan Dahl

items.description: Which technology is best for building a deployment platform for running third party code? Let's dive into the key differences in feature set, billing model, and performance.
items.title: Using Deno Subhosting vs. AWS Lambda to Run Untrusted User Code
items.author: Andy Jiang

items.description: Deno 1.40 introduces the Temporal API, TC39 decorators, and a range of deprecations and stabilizations, along with improvements in Node.js compatibility, LSP, diagnostics, and handling of unstable features, paving the way for a seamless upgrade to Deno 2.
items.title: Deno 1.40: Temporal API
items.author: Bartek Iwańczuk, Leo Kettmeir, Andy Jiang, Ryan Dahl, Divy Srivastava, Nayeem Rahman

items.description: This tutorial will show you how to build a simple cloud IDE using the Deno Subhosting API.
items.title: Build Your Own Cloud IDE with the Subhosting API
items.author: Kevin Whinnery, Andy Jiang

items.description: Details, prizes, submission guidelines, resources, and more about the Deno Subhosting Hackathon.
items.title: Build a Cloud IDE for the Deno Subhosting Hackathon
items.author: Andy Jiang, Kevin Whinnery

items.description: We've made a ton of improvements to our Node and npm compatibility this past year. Here's a chance for you to experience those improvements and win some prizes.
items.title: Run a Node project with Deno and win prizes in the #NodeToDenoChallenge
items.author: Andy Jiang

items.description: Learn to use text completions, image generation, image analysis, and more  features of OpenAI using their official Deno SDK.
items.title: Getting Started with the OpenAI SDK for Deno
items.author: Kevin Whinnery

items.description: We've re-added WebGPU, added new deno coverage reporters, made substantial Node.js compatibility improvements, and more.
items.title: Deno 1.39: The Return of WebGPU
items.author: Bartek Iwańczuk, Leo Kettmeir, Yoshiya Hinosawa, Andy Jiang, Ryan Dahl

items.description: We compare Deno KV to other serverless data stores on performance, price, developer experience, and more.
items.title: Deno KV vs. Cloudflare Workers KV, Upstash Redis, AWS DynamoDB, and Google Firestore
items.author: Andy Jiang

items.description: Access our zero config distributed database, Deno KV, in your Node projects with our new npm package.
items.title: Use Deno KV in Node with the new official npm package
items.author: John Spurlock, Igor Zinkovsky, Andy Jiang

items.description: Detecting changes in Deno KV with `kv.watch` makes it easier to build real-time applications like newsfeeds, analytics, multi-user collaboration  tools, and more.
items.title: Build Real-time Applications with the new "watch" API in Deno KV
items.author: Heyang Zhou, Andy Jiang

items.description: Terraform is a popular tool used to safely and predictably provision and manage infrastructure in any cloud. Here’s how you could use Terraform to manage your Deno Deploy or Deno Subhosting projects.
items.title: Manage your Deno Deploy and Deno Subhosting projects with Terraform
items.author: Ryan Betts, Yusuke Tanaka, Bert Belder, Andy Jiang

items.description: Discover new improvements in Fresh 1.6 that simplify your project and make it speedier.
items.title: Fresh 1.6: Tailwind CSS plugin, simplified typings and more
items.author: Marvin Hagemeister

items.description: `Deno.cron` allows you to easily create scheduled jobs and is available on Deno Deploy. Here's how it works.
items.title: Announcing Deno Cron
items.author: Igor Zinkovsky, Andy Jiang

items.description: Deno Deploy and Deno Subhosting was designed with security and tenant isolation in mind. Here's how it works.
items.title: How security and tenant isolation allows Deno Subhosting to run untrusted code securely
items.author: Bert Belder, Andy Jiang

items.description: Learn how using Deno improves the performance of Deco.cx's clients storefronts and increase page load speeds by 5x.
items.title: How Brazil's top ecommerce platform used Deno Subhosting to drive 5x faster page load speeds
items.author: Andy Jiang

items.description: Subhosting is a new way to leverage Deno Deploy's fast, scalable multi-tenant v8 isolate cloud to run your users code securely.
items.title: Deno Subhosting: the easiest and most secure way to run untrusted multi-tenant code
items.author: Alon Bonder, Bert Belder

items.description: Deno KV is now even more flexible and powerful with self-hosted options, replicas, and S3 and GCS continuous backup support.
items.title: Announcing self-hosted Deno KV, continuous backups, and replicas
items.author: Luca Casonato, Heyang Zhou, Andy Jiang

items.description: Deno 1.38 ships with HTML doc output, hot module replacement, improved Node.js compatibility by allowing you to use your own `node_modules` folder, and more.
items.title: Deno 1.38: HTML doc generator and HMR
items.author: Andy Jiang, Bartek Iwańczuk, David Sherret, Kevin Whinnery, Leo Kettmeir, Matt Mastracci, Nayeem Rahman, Yoshiya Hinosawa, Marvin Hagemeister

items.description: Discover new improvements in Fresh 1.5 that makes your site quicker to load and comes with several improvements to make authoring complex projects easier.
items.title: Fresh 1.5: Partials, client side navigation and more
items.author: Marvin Hagemeister

items.description: Introducing Deno Queues - zero config, scalable messaging with a guaranteed  at-least-once delivery. This new primitive builds on the foundation set by  Deno KV, and is available today in the Deno JavaScript runtime and Deno  Deploy.
items.title: Announcing Deno Queues
items.author: Ryan Dahl, Andy Jiang, Igor Zinkovsky

items.description: Join us to learn about the past, present, and future of Deno as we co-host  Deno Fest in Tokyo on October 20th!
items.title: Register for Deno Fest Tokyo, October 20th 2023
items.author: Yoshiya Hinosawa

items.description: Deno 1.37 ships with a Jupyter notebook integration and improved VSCode and LSP features.
items.title: Deno 1.37: Modern JavaScript in Jupyter Notebooks
items.author: Bartek Iwańczuk, Kevin Whinnery, David Sherret, Ryan Dahl, Yoshiya Hinosawa, Nayeem Rahman

items.description: With npm compatibility in Deno improving, and npm specifiers now available on  Deno Deploy, there are more options than ever to build web apps on Deno. Let's explore some options, including Fresh, SvelteKit, Nuxt/Vue, Astro, and beyond.
items.title: The State of Web Frameworks on Deno
items.author: Kevin Whinnery

items.description: How we built a performant, scalable, ACID-compliant, JavaScript-native database on FoundationDB.
items.title: Deno KV internals: building a database for the modern web
items.author: Heyang Zhou, Andy Jiang, Luca Casonato

items.description: Deno Deploy becomes the first isolate serverless platform to natively support more than two million modules on npm.
items.title: Announcing native npm support on Deno Deploy
items.author: Andy Jiang, Luca Casonato, Kevin Whinnery

items.description: Deno KV, the easiest way to add a strongly consistent database to your app, is now in open beta.
items.title: Deno KV is in Open Beta
items.author: Andy Jiang, Luca Casonato, Heyang Zhou

items.description: Here's how Deno's built-in tools and APIs make it easy to build a CLI and distribute it to all major platforms.
items.title: Build a Cross-Platform CLI with Deno in 5 minutes

items.description: Post-mortem report for the Deploy outage on August 22nd, 2023.
items.title: August 22nd, 2023 Deno Deploy Post-mortem
items.author: Heyang Zhou, Satya Rohith, Kevin Whinnery

items.description: Discover new improvements in Fresh 1.4 that makes your site quicker to load and comes with several improvements to make authoring complex projects easier.
items.title: Fresh 1.4 – Faster Page Loads, Layouts and More
items.author: Marvin Hagemeister

items.description: Why a Next.js project has over 30 configuration files and what we can do to avoid it.
items.title: Node.js's Config Hell Problem
items.author: Andy Jiang

items.description: Deno 1.36 introduces new runtime security options plus expanded testing and benchmarking APIs.
items.title: Deno 1.36: More flexible security and expanded testing APIs
items.author: Bartek Iwańczuk, Kevin Whinnery

items.description: How to write your module with modern tooling and transform it with `dnt` to support CommonJS, ESM, browsers, Deno, Node.js, TypeScript, and more.
items.title: dnt — the easiest way to publish a hybrid npm module for ESM and CommonJS
items.author: Andy Jiang

items.description: Deno is a critical part of distributing our own software and also helping our users manage their dependencies.
items.title: How the creator of Homebrew simplifies distributing software with tea and Deno

items.description: Learn how to build and deploy static and server-rendered apps with Astro on Deno and Deno Deploy.
items.title: Build and Ship Astro Sites with Deno and Deno Deploy
items.author: Kevin Whinnery

items.description: Explore the key improvements in Fresh 1.3: streamlined route components, enhanced error handling, updated linting rules, and multi-island exports. This release also supports the stable Deno.serve API, making Deno projects more efficient and manageable.
items.title: Fresh 1.3 – Simplified Route Components and More

items.description: Deno.serve() is stable, support for key npm packages, and more.
items.title: Deno 1.35: A fast and convenient way to build web servers

items.title: June 25th, 2023 Deno Deploy Postmortem

items.description: How CommonJS became Node's module system, ESM solved modules for the browser, and why supporting both slows down the JavaScript ecosystem.

items.description: What SOC 2 compliance for security, availability, and confidentiality means for Deno.

items.title: Fresh 1.2 – welcoming a full-time maintainer, sharing state between islands, limited npm support, and more

items.description: Rules, categories, prizes, and more about the Deno KV Hackathon.

items.description: This update augments compatibility with npm and Node.js, incorporates glob support, and enhances TLS certificates with IP addresses. It also brings forth improvements to the configuration, language server, APIs, and updates to V8 and TypeScript.
items.title: Deno 1.34: deno compile supports npm packages

items.description: Learnings from our recent survey and feedback from across our community. We'll discuss how we're addressing this feedback and the features to expect from Deno in the coming months.
items.title: Big Changes Ahead for Deno
items.author: Ryan Dahl, Alon Bonder

items.description: A walk-through of creating a CLI that executes JavaScript files.

items.description: Fresh is a new full stack web framework for Deno. By default, Fresh web pages send zero JavaScript to the client.

items.description: Series A led by Sequoia Capital

items.description: Deno Deploy runs Deno programs at the edge, now with support for static files.
items.title: Static Files on Deno Deploy

items.description: Have you ever wondered how web compatible Deno is? In this blog post I explain every single web API available in Deno.

items.description: Deno has joined the JavaScript standards committee to improve the language for everyone.
items.title: Deno joins TC39

items.description: Deno Deploy provides web standard streaming infrastructure to easily whip up real-time applications.

items.description: Today Slack has announced their next generation development platform. Slack chose Deno for its "secure by default" principles, its web standard APIs, and its first-class TypeScript support.
items.title: Slack Introduces New Platform With Help From Deno
items.author: Aaron O'Mullan, Ryan Dahl

items.description: Many serverless at edge products can not connect to Postgres because they don't support TCP. Deno Deploy can.

items.description: Deno 1.16 adds support for new JSX transforms, reading files from disk using fetch, and much more.

items.author: Luca Casonato, David Sherret, Kitson Kelly

items.description: Deno Deploy is a multi-tenant distributed JavaScript VM running in 28 data centers across the world.

items.description: Deno Deploy is a multi-tenant distributed JavaScript VM running in 25 data centers across the world.

items.description: Web compatibility data for Deno is now available on MDN.
items.title: Deno on MDN

items.description: Deno 1.13 stabilizes the native HTTP server, and introduces FFI, a streaming WebSocket API, the new self.structuredClone() function and more.

items.description: Post-mortem report for the 6 minute service outage on July 27, 2021.
items.title: July 27 incident update

items.description: The Deno 1.12 release adds server side WebSockets, support for WASM threads, new web crypto APIs and more.
items.title: Deno 1.12 Release Notes
items.author: Luca Casonato, Bartek Iwańczuk

items.description: Deno Deploy is a multi-tenant distributed JavaScript VM running in 25 data centers across the world.
items.title: Deno Deploy Beta 1
items.author: Ryan Dahl

items.description: The Deno 1.11 release adds new web APIs, resolves long standing issues, and improves editor experience.
items.title: Deno 1.11 Release Notes
items.author: Luca Casonato, Bartek Iwańczuk, Ryan Dahl, Kitson Kelly

items.description: Deno 1.10 improves the built-in test runner, adds support for Web Storage API, structured clone, and more.
items.title: Deno 1.10 Release Notes
items.author: Luca Casonato, Bartek Iwańczuk

items.description: Deno 1.9 adds a new native HTTP/2 web server, a vastly improved op infrastructure, import completions in the LSP, an interactive permission prompt, blob url support.
items.title: Deno 1.9 Release Notes
items.author: Bartek Iwańczuk, Luca Casonato, Ryan Dahl, Aaron O'Mullan

items.description: We have raised money to enable the millions of web programmers out there to maximally leverage their craft.
items.title: Announcing the Deno Company
items.author: Ryan Dahl, Bert Belder

items.description: Post-mortem report for the 98 minute service outage on March 2, 2021.
items.title: March 2 incident update
items.author: Luca Casonato

items.description: Deno 1.8 adds experimental support for the WebGPU API, adds support for importing private modules, stabilizes import maps, revamps coverage tooling, adds ICU to provide internationalization out of the box, and a whole lot more.
items.title: Deno 1.8 Release Notes
items.author: Bartek Iwańczuk, Luca Casonato, Ryan Dahl

items.description: Deno 1.7, one of our largest releases to date, adds cross compilation and 60% smaller binaries for deno compile, a DNS resolver API, support for data URLs in import statements and web workers, and much more.
items.title: Deno 1.7 Release Notes
items.author: Bartek Iwańczuk, Luca Casonato

items.description: Retrospect of what happened in Deno in 2020
items.title: Deno in 2020
items.author: Bartek Iwańczuk, Ryan Dahl

items.description: Deno 1.6 adds the ability to build your Deno projects into fully standalone, self-contained executables with `deno compile`. The release also introduces a built-in LSP for editor integrations, and experimental Apple Silicon support.
items.title: Deno 1.6 Release Notes
items.author: Bartek Iwańczuk, Luca Casonato, Ryan Dahl

items.description: Deno 1.5 improves `deno bundle` with support for tree shaking and a 15x speed improvement. This release also adds the `alert`, `confirm`, and `prompt` APIs and enhances the REPL.
items.title: Deno 1.5 Release Notes
items.author: Bartek Iwańczuk, Luca Casonato, Ryan Dahl

items.description: Deno 1.4 adds support for the web standard WebSocket API, deno run --watch, and integrated test coverage. This is the largest feature release yet.
items.title: Deno 1.4 Release Notes
items.author: Bartek Iwańczuk, Ryan Dahl, Luca Casonato

items.description: Design considerations and changes for the new code hosting service.
items.title: Updates to deno.land/x
items.author: Luca Casonato

items.description: Dynamic languages are useful tools. Scripting allows users to rapidly and succinctly tie together complex systems and express ideas without worrying about details like memory management or build systems.
items.title: Deno 1.0
items.author: Ryan Dahl, Bert Belder, Bartek Iwańczuk
